I used to get mad at my school (No, I can’t complain)
 The teachers who taught me weren’t cool (No, I can’t complain)

John Lennon and Paul McCartney were not very fond of teachers. A list of John’s detentions from Quarry Bank High School was found in 2015. It shows many of John’s actions, like “no [homework]“ and “impertinence,” as well as other disruptions from September 1955 to July 1956.



According to Many Years From Now by Barry Miles, Paul said:

The ‘angry young man’ and all that was John and I filling in the verses about schoolteachers. We shared a lot of feelings against teachers who had punished you too much or who hadn’t understood you or who had just been bastards generally.

–(via The Beatles Bible website)
A little better all the time (It can’t get no worse)

In his November 1997 biography, Many Years From Now, Paul McCartney said:

I was sitting there doing, “Getting better all the time,” and John just said in his laconic way, “It couldn’t get no worse.” I thought, “Oh, brilliant! This is exactly why I love writing with John.”

This is a typical example of McCartney and Lennon’s songwriting dynamic. Lennon once said:

Well, you could say that he [McCartney] provided a lightness, an optimism, while I would always go for the sadness, the discords, a certain bluesy edge.
I’m doing the best that I can

At this part of the song, McCartney somewhat clearly says:

You’re doing the best that I can.

This is a mistake. The backing tracks deliver the correct line, albeit more faintly:

I’m doing the best that I can.
You gave me the word, I finally heard

This could be a subtle reference to August 1966’s “The Word,” from Rubber Soul. The “word” is love, and John Lennon seems to be moving away from jealousy and anger, toward a better understanding of his surroundings.

Me used to be angry young man
 Me hiding me head in the sand

If you are “hiding your head in the sand,” you are irritable and stubborn when it comes to acknowledging unpleasant situations.



John, in particular, has acknowledged his violent tendencies on songs like “Run For Your Life from Rubber Soul.

You better run for your life if you can, little girl
Hide your head in the sand little girl

The awkward grammar is a reference to the first verse, highlighting the “angry young man”’s unsuccessful education.

I used to be cruel to my woman
 I beat her and kept her apart from the things that she loved
 Man, I was mean but I’m changing my scene
 And I’m doing the best that I can (Fool, you fool)

This verse was contributed by John Lennon, who had recently ended his unhappy first marriage. Lennon admitted to abusing his significant other in his youth:

All that ‘I used to be cruel to my woman, I beat her and kept her apart from the things that she loved’ was me. I used to be cruel to my woman, and physically – any woman. I was a hitter. I couldn’t express myself and I hit. I fought men and I hit women. That is why I am always on about peace, you see. It is the most violent people who go for love and peace. Everything’s the opposite. But I sincerely believe in love and peace. I am a violent man who has learned not to be violent and regrets his violence. I will have to be a lot older before I can face in public how I treated women as a youngster.

–from Lennon’s final interview with Playboy in 1980
